fmtvalue.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /*****************************************************************************
00002 
00003   Description:  This file contains routines that are used to format
00004                 ODL values for output.  Each routine converts a
00005                 specific type of data value from its internal ODLC
00006                 format to an ASCII text string.
00007 
00008   Author:  Randy Davis, University of Colorado LASP
00009 
00010   Creation Date: 22 March 1989
00011   Last Modified: 18 May 1991
00012 
00013   History:
00014 
00015     Creation - This module was introduced in the Version 1 release of the
00016     ODLC library.
00017 
00018     Version 2.0 - 03 November 1990 - R. Davis, U. of Colorado LASP
00019       a) Modified to be compatible with Version 2 data structures.
00020       b) Direct writing of output is eliminated: formatted values now
00021          returned in text strings.
00022       c) Changed names of routines from ODLPutx (for example, ODLPutString)
00023          to ODLFormatx (as in ODLFormatString) to reflect the fact that
00024          these routines no longer directly write their output.
00025       d) Cleaned up the code for routine ODLFormatString.
00026 
00027     Version 2.1 - 13 March 1991 - R. Davis, U. of Colorado LASP
00028       a) Modified the calling sequence to ODLFormatString so that the
00029          pointer to the current column is passed as argument column,
00030          and an updated value is returned.  This makes the routine
00031          format output correctly for arrays of strings and other
00032          situations that previously caused problems with excessively
00033          long lines of output.
00034       a) Added routine ODLFormatComment to format comments in labels.
00035 
00036   Version 2.2 - 18 May 1991 - M. DeMore, Jet Propulsion Laboratory
00037     Removed include statements that were Unix specific and placed them
00038     in odldef.h. Added include file odlinter.h.
00039 
00040   Version 2.3 - 13 October 1991 - M. DeMore, Jet Propulsion Laboratory.
00041     Added is_pointer input to ODLFormatString in order to cope with
00042     backslashes in DOS file names.
00043 
00044   26 October 1996, Alward N. Siyyid     Changed the value for MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN from
00045                     132 to 317 to allow for long words in a string
00046   
00047 *****************************************************************************/
00048     
00049 
00050 #include <ctype.h>
00051 #include <math.h>
00052 
00053 #include "odldef.h"
00054 #include "odlinter.h"
00055 
00056

00059 
00060 /*****************************************************************************
00061 
00062   Routine: ODLFormatInteger
00063  
00064   Description:  Formats an integer number for output, in decimal or based
00065                 format, and with or without units.
00066  
00067   Input:
00068            stmt  - Character string to receive formatted value.
00069            value - Pointer to a value data structure that contains the
00070                    value and associated formatting information.
00071 
00072   Output:  The value is formatted and returned in the string pointed
00073            to by the first parameter.  The count of characters
00074            placed into the output string is returned as the
00075            function value.
00076            
00077 *****************************************************************************/
00078 
00079 
00080 int ODLFormatInteger (char stmt[], VALUE_DATA *item)
00081 {
00082   char             digits[64];  /* Array to hold  string of digits          */
00083   int              base;        /* Number base                              */
00084   int              dnum;        /* Current digit of number                  */
00085   int              i;           /* Index into array                         */
00086   int              len;         /* Number of characters in output string    */
00087   unsigned long    num;         /* Used to hold number during conversion    */
00088 
00089 
00090   /* If the format is  0 then we are to print in standard signed decimal
00091      format. If format > 0, the value will be printed as an unsigned number
00092      using based notation.  A format value < 0 indicates an error and the
00093      value cannot be printed. */
00094 
00095   if (item->valid == 0)
00096     {
00097       sprintf (stmt, "**Error**");
00098       len = 9;
00099     }
00100   else
00101     {
00102       num = item->value.integer.number;
00103       if (item->format == 0)
00104         {
00105           sprintf (stmt, "%ld", num);
00106         }
00107       else
00108         {
00109           /* The output is to be in based notation. Convert the output a digit
00110              at a time, according to the specified base. We always put out at
00111              least one digit.  */
00112 
00113           i = 64;
00114           digits[--i] = '\0';
00115 
00116           if (item->format > 0)
00117             {
00118               /* The number is positive */
00119 
00120               base = item->format;
00121             }
00122           else
00123             {
00124               /* The number is negative: negate the value to be output */
00125 
00126               base = -item->format;
00127               num  = -num;
00128             } 
00129 
00130           do
00131             {
00132               dnum = num%base;
00133               digits[--i] = (dnum < 10) ? dnum + '0' : (dnum-10) + 'A';
00134               num = num/base; 
00135             } while (num > 0);
00136 
00137           if (item->format < (char) 0)
00138             {
00139               digits[--i] = '-';
00140             }
00141 
00142           sprintf (stmt, "%d#%s#",
00143                    base,
00144                    &digits[i]);
00145         }
00146 
00147       /* Determine the length of the number string */
00148 
00149       len = strlen (stmt);
00150 
00151       /* Put in the units associated with the number, if any */
00152 
00153       len += ODLFormatUnits (&stmt[len], item->value.integer.units);
00154     }
00155 
00156   return (len);
00157 }
00158

00160 
00161 
00162 /*****************************************************************************
00163 
00164   Routine: ODLFormatReal
00165  
00166   Description:  Formats a real number for output, with or without units.
00167  
00168   Input:
00169            output_file - A pointer to the file to which the output is to go.
00170            value       - Pointer to a value data structure that contains the
00171                          value and associated formatting information.
00172 
00173   Output:  The value is formatted and returned in the string pointed
00174            to by the first parameter.  The count of characters
00175            placed into the output string is returned as the
00176            function value.
00177            
00178 *****************************************************************************/
00179 
00180 
00181 int ODLFormatReal (char *stmt, VALUE_DATA *item)
00182 {
00183   int              len;         /* Number of characters in output string    */
00184 
00185 
00186   /* If the format value is < 0 then the value is in error and can't
00187       be output.  Otherwise format the value for output */
00188 
00189   if (item->valid == 0)
00190     {
00191       sprintf (stmt, "**Error**");
00192       len = 9;
00193     }
00194   else
00195     {
00196       if (item->format == 0)
00197         {
00198           /* Format the number using the general format */
00199 
00200           sprintf (stmt, "%g",
00201                    item->value.real.number);
00202         }
00203       else if (item->format == 1)
00204         {
00205           /* Format the number using the decimal format.  We
00206              always put in at least one decimal place */
00207 
00208           sprintf (stmt, "%.*f",
00209                    (item->precision <= 0)? 1 : item->precision,
00210                    item->value.real.number);
00211         }
00212       else
00213         {
00214           /* Format the number using the exponential format.  We
00215              always put in at least one decimal place */
00216 
00217           sprintf (stmt, "%.*e",
00218                    (item->precision <= 0)? 1 : item->precision,
00219                     item->value.real.number);
00220         }
00221 
00222       /* Determine the length of the number string */
00223 
00224       len = strlen (stmt);
00225 
00226       /* Put in the units associated with the number, if any */
00227 
00228       len += ODLFormatUnits (&stmt[len], item->value.real.units);
00229     }
00230 
00231   return (len);
00232 }
00233

00236 
00237 /*****************************************************************************
00238 
00239   Routine: ODLFormatUnits
00240  
00241   Description:  Formats the units of an integer or real number for output.
00242  
00243   Input:
00244            stmt  - Character string to receive formatted value.
00245            units - Pointer to the first units field.  If this value is
00246                    NULL then no units are present and the routine
00247                    does nothing.
00248 
00249   Output:  The units are formatted and returned in the string pointed
00250            to by the first parameter.  The count of characters
00251            placed into the output string is returned as the
00252            function value.
00253            
00254 *****************************************************************************/
00255 
00256 
00257 int ODLFormatUnits (char *stmt, struct ODLUnits *units)
00258 {
00259   struct ODLUnits *current_units;/* Pointer to current units field          */
00260   int              first_field; /* =1 if first units field; 0 otherwise     */
00261   int              uexp;        /* Units exponent value                     */
00262   int              len;         /* Number of characters in output string    */
00263 
00264 
00265   len = 0;
00266 
00267   if (units != NULL)
00268     {
00269      current_units = units;
00270 
00271      /* Start with the opening units expression delimiter */
00272 
00273      stmt[len++] = '<';
00274 
00275      /* Add in each field of the units expression */
00276 
00277      first_field = 1;
00278 
00279      while (current_units != NULL)
00280        {
00281          /* If this is not the first field put in a '*' if the field is
00282             being multiplied by the previous units or '/' if the field
00283             is being divided into the previous units */
00284 
00285          uexp = current_units->exponent;
00286 
00287          if (!first_field)
00288            {
00289              if (uexp > 0)
00290                {
00291                  stmt[len++] = '*';
00292                }      
00293 
00294              else
00295                {
00296                  stmt[len++] = '/';
00297                  uexp = -uexp;
00298                }
00299            }
00300          else
00301            {
00302              first_field = 0;
00303            }
00304 
00305          /* Put in the units */
00306 
00307          sprintf (&stmt[len], "%s",
00308                   current_units->designator);
00309          len += strlen (&stmt[len]);
00310 
00311          /* Put in the exponent, if appropriate */
00312 
00313          if (uexp != 1)
00314            {
00315              sprintf (&stmt[len], "**%d",
00316                       uexp);
00317              len += strlen (&stmt[len]);
00318            }
00319 
00320          /* Get the next units field, if any */
00321 
00322          current_units = current_units->next_field;
00323        }
00324 
00325      /* Put in the terminating delimiter for the units expression */
00326 
00327      stmt[len++] = '>';
00328      stmt[len] = '\0';
00329    }
00330 
00331   return (len);
00332 }

00336 
00337 /*****************************************************************************
00338 
00339   Routine: ODLFormatSymbol
00340  
00341   Description:  Formats a symbol, with or without delimiters.
00342  
00343   Input:
00344            stmt   - Character string to receive the formatted output.
00345            value  - Pointer to a value data structure that contains the
00346                     value and associated formatting information.
00347 
00348   Output:  The symbol is placed into the statement string and the number
00349            of characters put in the string is returned as the function
00350            value.
00351            
00352 *****************************************************************************/
00353 
00354 
00355 int ODLFormatSymbol (char *stmt, VALUE_DATA *item)
00356 {
00357   int              len;         /* Number of characters in output string    */
00358 
00359 
00360   /* Format the symbol.  If the format code is less than zero then the value
00361      has an error and can't be output.  If the format is greater than
00362      zero then the symbol is a name that doesn't require delimiters.
00363      Else, if format is zero, put the symbol between delimiters */
00364 
00365   if (item->valid == 0)
00366     {
00367       sprintf (stmt, "**Error**");
00368     }
00369   else if (item->format > 0)
00370     {
00371       sprintf (stmt, "%s",
00372                item->value.string);
00373     }
00374   else
00375     {
00376       sprintf (stmt, "\'%s\'",
00377                item->value.string);
00378     }
00379 
00380   /* Determine the length of the formatted string */
00381 
00382   len = strlen (stmt);
00383 
00384   return (len);
00385 }

00389 
00390 /*****************************************************************************
00391 
00392   Routine: ODLFormatDate
00393  
00394   Description:  Formats a date for output, either as year-month-day or
00395                 year-doy.
00396  
00397   Input:
00398           stmt   - Character string to receive formatted output.
00399           value  - Pointer to a value data structure that contains the
00400                    value and associated formatting information.
00401 
00402   Output:  The formatted value is placed into the statement string and the
00403            number of characters put in the string is returned as the
00404            function value.
00405 
00406 *****************************************************************************/
00407 
00408 
00409 int ODLFormatDate (char *stmt, VALUE_DATA *item)
00410 {
00411 /* >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> BEGIN CN CHANGES >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> */
00412 /* >>>>> MDD 5/26/91  Removed declarations of unused variables     >>>>> */
00413 /* >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> */
00414 
00415   int     day;                  /* Day of month (1-31)                      */
00416   int     doy;                  /* Day of year (1-366)                      */
00417   int     month;                /* Month (1-12)                             */
00418   int     year;                 /* Year                                     */
00419   int     len;                  /* Number of characters in output string    */
00420 
00421 /* >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> END OF CN CHANGES >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> */
00422 
00423 
00424   /* If the format flag is less than zero then there is an error in the
00425      value and we can't format it for output */
00426 
00427   if (item->valid == 0)
00428     {
00429       sprintf (stmt, "**Error**");
00430     }
00431   else
00432     {
00433       /* Get the components of the date */
00434 
00435       year  = (int) item->value.date_time.year;
00436       doy   = (int) item->value.date_time.doy;
00437       month = (int) item->value.date_time.month;
00438       day   = (int) item->value.date_time.day;
00439 
00440       if (item->format/10 == 3)
00441         {
00442           /* Format the date as year, month and day-of-month */
00443 
00444           sprintf (stmt, "%d-%02d-%02d",
00445                    year, month, day);
00446         }
00447       else
00448         {
00449 
00450           /* Format the date as year and day-of-year */
00451 
00452           sprintf (stmt, "%d-%03d",
00453                    year, doy);
00454         } 
00455     }
00456 
00457   /* Determine the length of the formatted string */
00458 
00459   len = strlen (stmt);
00460 
00461   return (len);
00462 }
00463

00465 
00466 
00467 /*****************************************************************************
00468 
00469   Routine: ODLFormatTime
00470  
00471   Description:  Formats a time and time zone indicator for output.
00472  
00473   Input:
00474            stmt   - Character string to receive formatted output.
00475            value  - Pointer to a value data structure that contains the
00476                     value and associated formatting information.
00477 
00478   Output:  The formatted value is placed into the statement string.  The
00479            function returns the number of characters put in the string.
00480            
00481 *****************************************************************************/
00482 
00483 
00484 int ODLFormatTime (char *stmt, VALUE_DATA *item)
00485 {
00486   int     hours;                /* Hours of day (0-23) and time zone hours  */
00487   int     minutes;              /* Minutes of hour (0-59) and time zone mins*/
00488   double  seconds;              /* Seconds of minute (<60.0)                */
00489   int     len;                  /* Number of characters in output string    */
00490 
00491 
00492   if (item->valid == 0)
00493     {
00494       sprintf (stmt, "**Error**");
00495       len = 9;
00496     }
00497   else
00498     {
00499       /* Get the components of the time */
00500 
00501       hours   = (int) item->value.date_time.hours;
00502       minutes = (int) item->value.date_time.minutes;
00503       seconds = (double) item->value.date_time.seconds +
00504                 (double) item->value.date_time.nanoseconds*1.0E-9;
00505 
00506       /* Put out the hours, minutes and seconds (always two
00507          digits apiece) */
00508      
00509       sprintf (stmt, "%02d:%02d",
00510                hours, minutes);
00511       len = 5;
00512 
00513       if (item->format % 10 == 3)
00514         {
00515           /* Put out seconds part of time as well */
00516 
00517       stmt[len++] = ':';
00518 
00519           if (seconds < 10.0)
00520             {
00521               stmt[len++] = '0';
00522             }
00523           sprintf (&stmt[len], "%.*f",
00524                    item->precision,
00525                    seconds);
00526           len += strlen (&stmt[len]);
00527         }
00528 
00529       /* Put out the time zone.  If UTC, output a 'Z'; otherwise
00530          output the number of hours from Greenwich */
00531 
00532       hours   = (int) item->value.date_time.zone_hours;
00533       minutes = (int) item->value.date_time.zone_minutes;
00534 
00535       if (hours == 0)
00536         {
00537           stmt[len++] = 'Z';
00538           stmt[len] = '\0';
00539         }
00540       else
00541         {
00542           /* Put out hours part of time zone offset */
00543 
00544           sprintf (&stmt[len], "%+03d",
00545                    hours);
00546           len += 3;
00547 
00548           if (minutes != 0)
00549             {
00550               /* Put out minutes part of time zone offset also */
00551 
00552               sprintf (&stmt[len], ":%02d",
00553                        minutes);
00554               len += 3;
00555             }
00556         }
00557     }
00558 
00559   return (len);
00560 }
00561 
00562 
00563 
00564 
00565 /*****************************************************************************
00566 
00567   Routine: ODLFormatDateTime
00568  
00569   Description:  Formats a date and time for output.
00570  
00571   Input:
00572            stmt    - Character string to received formatted result.
00573            value   - Pointer to a value data structure that contains the
00574                      value and associated formatting information.
00575 
00576   Output:  The formatted value is placed into the statement string.  The
00577            function returns the number of characters put in the string.
00578            
00579 *****************************************************************************/
00580 
00581 
00582 int ODLFormatDateTime (char *stmt, VALUE_DATA *item)
00583 {
00584   int     len;                  /* Number of characters in output string    */
00585 
00586 
00587   /* If the format is less than zero then the value has an error and can't
00588      be printed.  Else print the date and time with a 'T' in between as
00589      a separator. */
00590 
00591   if (item->valid == 0)
00592     {
00593       sprintf (stmt, "**Error**");
00594       len = 9;
00595     }
00596   else
00597     {
00598       len = ODLFormatDate (stmt, item);
00599       stmt[len++] = 'T';
00600       len += ODLFormatTime (&stmt[len], item);
00601     }
00602 
00603   return (len);
00604 }
00605 
00606 
00607 
00608 
00609 /*****************************************************************************
00610                                                                            
00611   ODLFormatString:  Format an ODL string value for output.
00612 
00613   Input:
00614          stmt         - Character string to receive formatted output.
00615          value        - Pointer to a value data structure that contains
00616                         the value and associated formatting information.
00617          column       - Pointer to current column number.  Upon return,
00618                         the value will be updated to point to the next
00619                         column after the terminating  quotation mark.
00620          left_margin  - Starting column number for lines 2 and beyond,
00621                         counting from 1.
00622          right_margin - Last column for text on all lines.
00623          format_flag  - Set to TRUE if the '\t's and '\n's in the string
00624                         are not be be expanded on output (PDS label format).
00625          is_pointer   - Set to TRUE if the string being processed was part
00626                         of a pointer attribute, in which case '\t's and '\n's 
00627                         in the string aren't touched.
00628 
00629   Output:  The formatted string is placed into the statement string and the
00630            number of characters put in the string is returned as the
00631            function value.
00632                                                        
00633  ****************************************************************************/
00634 
00635 
00636 int ODLFormatString (char stmt[], VALUE_DATA *item, int *column, 
00637                      int left_margin, int right_margin, int format_flag, 
00638                      int is_pointer)
00639 
00640 {
00641   char   *text;                 /* Pointer to input string                  */
00642   char    c;                    /* Current input character                  */
00643   int     i;                    /* Loop index                               */
00644   int     l;                    /* Current column number                    */
00645   int     m;                    /* Index into input string                  */
00646   int     n;                    /* Length of input string                   */
00647   int     lmargin;              /* Adjusted left margin for line 2 & beyond */
00648   int     rmargin;              /* Adjusted right margin                    */
00649   int     endline;              /* TRUE if at end-of-line                   */
00650   int     len;                  /* Number of characters in output string    */
00651 
00652 #define indentf(X) for (i=0 ; i < X ; i++) stmt[len++] = ' '
00653 
00654 #define TAB_SIZE 8
00655 #define MIN_LINE_LENGTH 40
00656 #define MAX_LEFT_MARGIN 32
00657 /*
00658 #define MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN 132
00659 */
00660 #define MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN 317
00661 
00662 
00663   /* Check the line margin values and adjust them if they are out of range */
00664      
00665   if (left_margin < 1)
00666     {
00667       lmargin = 1;
00668     }
00669   else if (left_margin > MAX_LEFT_MARGIN)
00670     {
00671       lmargin = MAX_LEFT_MARGIN;
00672     }
00673   else
00674     {
00675       lmargin = left_margin;
00676     }
00677 
00678   if (right_margin > MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN)
00679     {
00680       rmargin = MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN;
00681     }
00682   else if (right_margin < lmargin+MIN_LINE_LENGTH)
00683     {
00684       rmargin = lmargin + MIN_LINE_LENGTH;
00685     }
00686   else
00687     {
00688       rmargin = right_margin;
00689     }
00690 
00691   /* Initialize counters and flags */
00692 
00693   l = (*column > 0)? *column : 1;
00694   endline = 0;
00695   len = 0;
00696 
00697   if (l > rmargin)
00698     {
00699       /* We're beyond the right margin already, so start a new one before
00700          starting the string */
00701       
00702       stmt[len++] = '\n';
00703       indentf (lmargin);
00704       l = lmargin;
00705     }
00706 
00707   /* Put out the opening quotation mark string delimiter */
00708 
00709   stmt[len++] =  '\"';
00710   l++;
00711 
00712   /* Scan through all of the input string, formatting as we go */
00713 
00714   text = item->value.string;
00715   n = item->length;
00716 
00717   for ( m = 0 ; m < n ; )
00718     {
00719       c = text[m++];
00720       if (!is_pointer && c == '\\')
00721       {
00722          c = text[m++];
00723          switch (c)
00724          {
00725            case 'n':
00726 
00727             /* We encountered an explicit newline: go put out the line */
00728 
00729             if (format_flag)
00730               {
00731                 stmt[len++] = '\\';
00732                 stmt[len++] = 'n';
00733                 l += 2;
00734               }
00735 
00736             endline = 1;
00737             break;
00738 
00739           case 't':
00740 
00741             /* Character is a horizontal tab */
00742 
00743             if (format_flag)
00744               {
00745                 /* The output is being formatted in PDS label format, so
00746                    indicate the tab explicitly */
00747 
00748                 stmt[len++] = '\\';
00749                 stmt[len++] = 't';
00750                 l += 2;
00751               }
00752             else
00753               {
00754                 /* The output is being formatted as normal text so expand the
00755                    tab if there is room on the line; if the tab comes at the
00756                    end of the line it can be discarded */
00757 
00758                 if (l+TAB_SIZE < rmargin)
00759                   {
00760                     indentf (TAB_SIZE);
00761                     l += TAB_SIZE;
00762                   }
00763                 else
00764                   {
00765                     endline = 1;
00766                   }
00767               }
00768              break;
00769 
00770         default:
00771                stmt[len++] = '\\';
00772                stmt[len++] = c;
00773                l+=2;
00774                break;
00775             }
00776           } 
00777           else
00778           {
00779             /* Add the character to the line.  */
00780 
00781             stmt[len++] = c;
00782             l++;
00783 
00784             if (l > rmargin)
00785               {
00786                 /* The current output line is full.  See if the next
00787                    character is a blank or tab */
00788 
00789                 if (m < n && isspace (text[m]))
00790                   {
00791                     /* It is: skip forward to the next non-blank character */
00792 
00793                     for ( ; m < n && isspace (text[m]) ; m++);
00794                   }
00795                 else
00796                   {
00797                     /* It is not: move back to a previous space character
00798                        to perform word wrapping. */
00799 
00800                     while (l > lmargin && len > 1 && !isspace (stmt[len-1]))
00801                       {
00802                         len--;
00803                         l--;
00804                         m--;
00805                       }
00806                   }
00807 
00808                 endline = 1;
00809               }
00810       }
00811 
00812       /* If we're at the end of a line, print it out and start a new line
00813          at the left margin */
00814     
00815       if (endline)  
00816         {
00817           stmt[len++] = '\n';
00818           indentf (lmargin);
00819           l = lmargin;
00820           endline = 0;
00821         }            
00822     }
00823 
00824   /* Put out the terminating quotation mark string delimiter and return
00825      the location of the next available print column */
00826 
00827   stmt[len++] = '\"';
00828   stmt[len] = '\0';
00829   *column = l+2;
00830 
00831   return (len);
00832 }
00833 
00834 
00835 
00836 
00837 /*****************************************************************************
00838 
00839   Routine: ODLFormatComment
00840  
00841   Description:  Formats a comment for insertion into a label
00842  
00843   Input:
00844            stmt    - Character string to receive the formatted output.
00845            comment - Character string containing the comment.
00846 
00847   Output:  The comment is placed into the statement string and the number
00848            of characters put in the string is returned as the function
00849            value.
00850            
00851 *****************************************************************************/
00852 
00853 
00854 int ODLFormatComment (char *stmt, char *comment, int left_margin, 
00855                       int right_margin)
00856 {
00857   char    c;                    /* Current input character                  */
00858   int     i;                    /* Loop index                               */
00859   int     l;                    /* Index into output line                   */
00860   int     ic;                   /* Index into comment string                */
00861   int     len;                  /* Number of characters in output string    */
00862   int     lmargin;              /* Adjusted left margin                     */
00863   int     rmargin;              /* Adjusted right margin                    */
00864 
00865 #define indentf(X) for (i=0 ; i < X ; i++) stmt[len++] = ' '
00866 
00867 #define MIN_LINE_LENGTH 40
00868 #define MAX_LEFT_MARGIN 32
00869 #define MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN 317
00870 
00871 
00872   if (comment == NULL)
00873     {
00874       return (0);
00875     }
00876 
00877   /* Check the line margin values and adjust them if they are out of range */
00878      
00879   if (left_margin < 1)
00880     {
00881       lmargin = 1;
00882     }
00883   else if (left_margin > MAX_LEFT_MARGIN)
00884     {
00885       lmargin = MAX_LEFT_MARGIN;
00886     }
00887   else
00888     {
00889       lmargin = left_margin;
00890     }
00891 
00892   if (right_margin > MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN)
00893     {
00894       rmargin = MAX_RIGHT_MARGIN;
00895     }
00896   else if (right_margin < lmargin+MIN_LINE_LENGTH)
00897     {
00898       rmargin = lmargin + MIN_LINE_LENGTH;
00899     }
00900   else
00901     {
00902       rmargin = right_margin;
00903     }
00904 
00905   rmargin = rmargin - 3;
00906 
00907   /* Put out the slash and asterisk to start the first comment line */
00908 
00909   len = 0;
00910   stmt[len++] = '\n';
00911   indentf (lmargin-1);
00912   stmt[len++] = '/';
00913   stmt[len++] = '*';
00914   l = lmargin+2;
00915 
00916   for (ic = 0 ; (c = comment[ic]) != '\0' ; ic++)
00917     {
00918       if (c == '\n' || l > rmargin)
00919         {
00920           /* This is the end of a line: put out the asterisk and slash
00921              that terminate the current line */
00922 
00923           stmt[len++] = ' ';
00924           stmt[len++] = '*';
00925           stmt[len++] = '/';
00926           stmt[len++] = '\n';
00927 
00928           /* Put out the slash and asterisk that start a new comment line */
00929 
00930           indentf (lmargin-1);
00931           stmt[len++] = '/';
00932           stmt[len++] = '*';
00933           l = lmargin+2;
00934         }
00935 
00936       if (c != '\n')
00937         {
00938           /* Put the current character into the output line */
00939 
00940           stmt[len++] = c;
00941           l++;
00942         }
00943     }
00944 
00945   /* Terminate the last line of the comment */
00946 
00947   stmt[len++] = ' ';
00948   stmt[len++] = '*';
00949   stmt[len++] = '/';
00950   stmt[len++] = '\n';
00951   stmt[len++] = '\n';
00952   stmt[len] = '\0';
00953 
00954   return (len);
00955 }
